question_title: Will Russia and Ukraine sign a ceasefire agreement before May 1, 2026?
summary: Despite unprecedented diplomatic activity in January 2026—including first-ever trilateral talks, US envoy meetings with Putin, and European security commitments—Russia publicly rejected key terms just 2 days ago. Foreign Minister Lavrov dismissed Ukraine's security demands and reiterated that the current Ukrainian government must go. Putin continues demanding maximalist positions (full territorial control, no Western troops) that Ukraine cannot accept. The structural incompatibility remains: Russia insists on comprehensive settlement before any ceasefire, while Ukraine needs the ceasefire first. Market consensus (Polymarket 13% for March 31, 27% for June 30) suggests ~18% for May 1. With only 3 months remaining and fundamental positions unchanged, a ceasefire by May 1 requires a dramatic breakthrough that appears unlikely given Russia's recent explicit rejection.

factors.description: Russia rejected key terms on January 29, 2026 - Lavrov dismissed security guarantees and demanded Ukrainian government change
Putin's maximalist demands - full control of annexed regions, no Western troops - are non-starters for Ukraine
Sequencing incompatibility - Russia demands comprehensive settlement before ceasefire, Ukraine needs ceasefire first
Russian military momentum - advancing on front lines, believes it is winning, no incentive to stop
Historical pattern of failed negotiations since 2022 (Minsk, Istanbul talks)
Short timeline (3 months) for complex multi-party international agreement
Unprecedented diplomatic activity - first trilateral talks, European security commitments, active US involvement
Strong US pressure - Trump administration actively pushing for deal, envoys meeting Putin directly
Polymarket consensus at 13% for March 31 (higher volume, calibrated market)
